qas.question: What was the Taft Vale Case?

answers.text: a dispute between strikers and a railway company

qas.question: How much were they ordered to pay in damages for the strike?
What hurt support for the LRC?
How much did the railway company have to pay the union?
What appeared to be very concerned with the industrial proletariat?
What refused to listen to industrial and business interests?

context: Support for the LRC was boosted by the 1901 <a0_0><b4_0>Taff Vale Case<b4_0/><a0_0/>, <a1_0>a dispute between strikers and a railway company<a1_0/> that ended with the union being ordered to pay <a3_0><b5_0>£23,000<b5_0/><a3_0/> damages for a strike. The <b6_0>judgement<b6_0/> effectively <a2_0>made strikes illegal<a2_0/> since employers could recoup the cost of lost business from the unions. The apparent acquiescence of the <b8_0>Conservative Government<b8_0/> of Arthur Balfour to industrial and business interests (traditionally the allies of the Liberal Party in opposition to the Conservative's landed interests) intensified support for the LRC against a <b7_0>government<b7_0/> that appeared to have little concern for the industrial proletariat and its problems.
